author: HCAndersen
text: "IT is so delightfully cold," said the Snow Man, "that it makes my whole body crackle.

author: HCAndersen
text: This is just the kind of wind to blow life into one.

author: HCAndersen
text: How that great red thing up there is staring at me!"

author: HCAndersen
text: He meant the sun, who was just setting.

author: HCAndersen
text: "It shall not make me wink.

author: HCAndersen
text: I shall manage to keep the pieces."

author: HCAndersen
text: He had two triangular pieces of tile in his head, instead of eyes; his mouth was made of an old broken rake, and was, of course, furnished with teeth.

author: HCAndersen
text: He had been brought into existence amidst the joyous shouts of boys, the jingling of sleigh-bells, and the slashing of whips.

author: HCAndersen
text: The sun went down, and the full moon rose, large, round, and clear, shining in the deep blue.

author: HCAndersen
text: "There it comes again, from the other side," said the Snow Man, who supposed the sun was showing himself once more.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Ah, I have cured him of staring, though; now he may hang up there, and shine, that I may see myself.

author: HCAndersen
text: If I only knew how to manage to move away from this place,- I should so like to move.

author: HCAndersen
text: If I could, I would slide along yonder on the ice, as I have seen the boys do; but I don't understand how; I don't even know how to run."

author: HCAndersen
text: "Away, away," barked the old yard-dog.

author: HCAndersen
text: He was quite hoarse, and could not pronounce "Bow wow" properly.

author: HCAndersen
text: He had once been an indoor dog, and lay by the fire, and he had been hoarse ever since.

author: HCAndersen
text: "The sun will make you run some day.

author: HCAndersen
text: I saw him, last winter, make your predecessor run, and his predecessor before him.

author: HCAndersen
text: Away, away, they all have to go."

author: HCAndersen
text: "I don't understand you, comrade," said the Snow Man.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Is that thing up yonder to teach me to run?

author: HCAndersen
text: I saw it running itself a little while ago, and now it has come creeping up from the other side.

author: HCAndersen
text: "You know nothing at all," replied the yard-dog; "but then, you've only lately been patched up.

author: HCAndersen
text: What you see yonder is the moon, and the one before it was the sun.

author: HCAndersen
text: It will come again to-morrow, and most likely teach you to run down into the ditch by the well; for I think the weather is going to change.

author: HCAndersen
text: I can feel such pricks and stabs in my left leg; I am sure there is going to be a change."

author: HCAndersen
text: "I don't understand him," said the Snow Man to himself; "but I have a feeling that he is talking of something very disagreeable.

author: HCAndersen
text: The one who stared so just now, and whom he calls the sun, is not my friend; I can feel that too."

author: HCAndersen
text: "Away, away," barked the yard-dog, and then he turned round three times, and crept into his kennel to sleep.

author: HCAndersen
text: There was really a change in the weather.

author: HCAndersen
text: Towards morning, a thick fog covered the whole country round, and a keen wind arose, so that the cold seemed to freeze one's bones; but when the sun rose, the sight was splendid.

author: HCAndersen
text: Trees and bushes were covered with hoar frost, and looked like a forest of white coral; while on every twig glittered frozen dew-drops.

author: HCAndersen
text: The many delicate forms concealed in summer by luxuriant foliage, were now clearly defined, and looked like glittering lace-work.

author: HCAndersen
text: From every twig glistened a white radiance.

author: HCAndersen
text: The birch, waving in the wind, looked full of life, like trees in summer; and its appearance was wondrously beautiful.

author: HCAndersen
text: And where the sun shone, how everything glittered and sparkled, as if diamond dust had been strewn about; while the snowy carpet of the earth appeared as if covered with diamonds, from which countless lights gleamed, whiter than even the snow itself.

author: HCAndersen
text: "This is really beautiful," said a young girl, who had come into the garden with a young man; and they both stood still near the Snow Man, and contemplated the glittering scene.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Summer cannot show a more beautiful sight," she exclaimed, while her eyes sparkled.

author: HCAndersen
text: "And we can't have such a fellow as this in the summer time," replied the young man, pointing to the Snow Man; "he is capital."

author: HCAndersen
text: The girl laughed, and nodded at the Snow Man, and then tripped away over the snow with her friend.

author: HCAndersen
text: The snow creaked and crackled beneath her feet, as if she had been treading on starch.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Who are these two?" asked the Snow Man of the yard-dog.

author: HCAndersen
text: "You have been here longer than I have; do you know them?"

author: HCAndersen
text: "Of course I know them," replied the yard-dog; "she has stroked my back many times, and he has given me a bone of meat.

author: HCAndersen
text: I never bite those two."

author: HCAndersen
text: "But what are they?" asked the Snow Man.

author: HCAndersen
text: "They are lovers," he replied; "they will go and live in the same kennel by-and-by, and gnaw at the same bone.

author: HCAndersen
text: Away, away!"

author: HCAndersen
text: "Are they the same kind of beings as you and I?" asked the Snow Man.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Well, they belong to the same master," retorted the yard-dog.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Certainly people who were only born yesterday know very little.

author: HCAndersen
text: I can see that in you.

author: HCAndersen
text: I have age and experience.

author: HCAndersen
text: I know every one here in the house, and I know there was once a time when I did not lie out here in the cold, fastened to a chain.

author: HCAndersen
text: Away, away!"

author: HCAndersen
text: "The cold is delightful," said the Snow Man; "but do tell me tell me; only you must not clank your chain so; for it jars all through me when you do that."

author: HCAndersen
text: "Away, away!" barked the yard-dog; "I'll tell you; they said I was a pretty little fellow once; then I used to lie in a velvet-covered chair, up at the master's house, and sit in the mistress's lap.

author: HCAndersen
text: They used to kiss my nose, and wipe my paws with an embroidered handkerchief, and I was called 'Ami, dear Ami, sweet Ami.'

author: HCAndersen
text: But after a while I grew too big for them, and they sent me away to the housekeeper's room; so I came to live on the lower story.

author: HCAndersen
text: You can look into the room from where you stand, and see where I was master once; for I was indeed master to the housekeeper.

author: HCAndersen
text: It was certainly a smaller room than those up stairs; but I was more comfortable; for I was not being continually taken hold of and pulled about by the children as I had been.

author: HCAndersen
text: I received quite as good food, or even better.

author: HCAndersen
text: I had my own cushion, and there was a stove- it is the finest thing in the world at this season of the year.

author: HCAndersen
text: I used to go under the stove, and lie down quite beneath it.

author: HCAndersen
text: Ah, I still dream of that stove.

author: HCAndersen
text: Away, away!"

author: HCAndersen
text: "Does a stove look beautiful?" asked the Snow Man, "is it at all like me?"

author: HCAndersen
text: "It is just the reverse of you,' said the dog; "it's as black as a crow, and has a long neck and a brass knob; it eats firewood, so that fire spurts out of its mouth.

author: HCAndersen
text: We should keep on one side, or under it, to be comfortable.

author: HCAndersen
text: You can see it through the window, from where you stand."

author: HCAndersen
text: Then the Snow Man looked, and saw a bright polished thing with a brazen knob, and fire gleaming from the lower part of it.

author: HCAndersen
text: The Snow Man felt quite a strange sensation come over him; it was very odd, he knew not what it meant, and he could not account for it.

author: HCAndersen
text: But there are people who are not men of snow, who understand what it is.

author: HCAndersen
text: "'And why did you leave her?" asked the Snow Man, for it seemed to him that the stove must be of the female sex.

author: HCAndersen
text: "How could you give up such a comfortable place?"

author: HCAndersen
text: "I was obliged," replied the yard-dog.

author: HCAndersen
text: "They turned me out of doors, and chained me up here.

author: HCAndersen
text: I had bitten the youngest of my master's sons in the leg, because he kicked away the bone I was gnawing.

author: HCAndersen
text: 'Bone for bone,' I thought; but they were so angry, and from that time I have been fastened with a chain, and lost my bone.

author: HCAndersen
text: Don't you hear how hoarse I am.

author: HCAndersen
text: Away, away!

author: HCAndersen
text: I can't talk any more like other dogs.

author: HCAndersen
text: Away, away, that is the end of it all."

author: HCAndersen
text: But the Snow Man was no longer listening.

author: HCAndersen
text: He was looking into the housekeeper's room on the lower storey; where the stove stood on its four iron legs, looking about the same size as the Snow Man himself.

author: HCAndersen
text: "What a strange crackling I feel within me," he said.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Shall I ever get in there?

author: HCAndersen
text: It is an innocent wish, and innocent wishes are sure to be fulfilled.

author: HCAndersen
text: I must go in there and lean against her, even if I have to break the window."

author: HCAndersen
text: "You must never go in there," said the yard-dog, "for if you approach the stove, you'll melt away, away."

author: HCAndersen
text: "I might as well go," said the Snow Man, "for I think I am breaking up as it is."

author: HCAndersen
text: During the whole day the Snow Man stood looking in through the window, and in the twilight hour the room became still more inviting, for from the stove came a gentle glow, not like the sun or the moon; no, only the bright light which gleams from a stove when it has been well fed.

author: HCAndersen
text: When the door of the stove was opened, the flames darted out of its mouth; this is customary with all stoves.

author: HCAndersen
text: The light of the flames fell directly on the face and breast of the Snow Man with a ruddy gleam.

author: HCAndersen
text: "I can endure it no longer," said he; "how beautiful it looks when it stretches out its tongue?"

author: HCAndersen
text: The night was long, but did not appear so to the Snow Man, who stood there enjoying his own reflections, and crackling with the cold.

author: HCAndersen
text: In the morning, the window-panes of the housekeeper's room were covered with ice.

author: HCAndersen
text: They were the most beautiful ice-flowers any Snow Man could desire, but they concealed the stove.

author: HCAndersen
text: These window-panes would not thaw, and he could see nothing of the stove, which he pictured to himself, as if it had been a lovely human being.

author: HCAndersen
text: The snow crackled and the wind whistled around him; it was just the kind of frosty weather a Snow Man might thoroughly enjoy.

author: HCAndersen
text: But he did not enjoy it; how, indeed, could he enjoy anything when he was "stove sick?"

author: HCAndersen
text: "That is terrible disease for a Snow Man," said the yard-dog; "I have suffered from it myself, but I got over it.

author: HCAndersen
text: Away, away," he barked and then he added, "the weather is going to change."

author: HCAndersen
text: And the weather did change; it began to thaw.

author: HCAndersen
text: As the warmth increased, the Snow Man decreased.

author: HCAndersen
text: He said nothing and made no complaint, which is a sure sign.

author: HCAndersen
text: One morning he broke, and sunk down altogether; and, behold, where he had stood, something like a broomstick remained sticking up in the ground.

author: HCAndersen
text: It was the pole round which the boys had built him up.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Ah, now I understand why he had such a great longing for the stove," said the yard-dog.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Why, there's the shovel that is used for cleaning out the stove, fastened to the pole."

author: HCAndersen
text: The Snow Man had a stove scraper in his body; that was what moved him so.

author: HCAndersen
text: "But it's all over now.

author: HCAndersen
text: Away, away."

author: HCAndersen
text: And soon the winter passed.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Away, away," barked the hoarse yard-dog.

author: HCAndersen
text: But the girls in the house sang,

author: HCAndersen
text: "Come from your fragrant home, green thyme; Stretch your soft branches, willow-tree; The months are bringing the sweet spring-time, When the lark in the sky sings joyfully.

author: HCAndersen
text: Come gentle sun, while the cuckoo sings, And I'll mock his note in my wanderings."

author: HCAndersen
text: And nobody thought any more of the Snow Man.
